awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: A Cloud Managed Solution for Public Transit Signal Priority and Emergency Vehicle Preemption of Traffic Lights
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to lay a foundation for vehicle to infrastructure communication focused on applications that add direct value to mobility. Many solutions are focused on getting information to the vehicle, while it is often the infrastructure that requires vehicle information to operate more efficiently. Currently, traffic signals enforce the right-of-way of everyone regardless of in-vehicle technology. This is why optimizing their effects on the road network can provide tremendous benefit. There are significant benefits to transit as well, like buses and light rail that, when given priority at intersections, improves on-time performance which is a major factor in ridership rates.

The proposed project advances the work of the joint standardization of the National Transportation Communications for Intelligent Transportation Systems Protocol (NTCIP) to achieve interoperability between various traffic signal controller vendors to enable shared control and organization between different operating agencies. It is not unusual to have sections of roadway be managed by local, county, and state within the same small area. These overlapping jurisdictions produce fractures within the road network resulting in the asynchronous timing of traffic signals. The aim is to consolidate the management into a signal network capable of coordinating large areas of traffic signals to increase mobility's overall efficiency. With a cloud solution that is capable of speaking to each networked intersection, vehicle telemetry data and route information can be used to proactively optimize signal timing. Working with prioritized vehicles such as buses, fire trucks, and ambulances, pilot studies will be conducted to perform priority and preemption along routes that cross jurisdictions. Each pilot case will be analysed based on key performance indicators set forth by the agencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The average American now spends around 42 hours per year in traffic, up from 16 hours per year in 1982. Gridlock is no longer constrained to the metropolitan areas, as suburban commuters are now dealing with it closer to home. Signalized intersections directly negatively impact the flow of traffic by design. Unfortunately, traffic lights also cause a significant amount of rear-end collisions and degrade overall intersection safety and efficiency. One-quarter of all accidents and one-third of all fatal accidents occur at intersections. The risk is even higher for active emergency vehicles since unpredictable traffic lights and distracted drivers cause side-impact collisions in addition to impeding right-of-way and lengthening their response time.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II and Phase IIB project advances the work to achieve interoperable traffic management between various traffic signal controller vendors to enable shared control and organization between different traffic control agencies. It is not unusual to have sections of roadway be managed by multiple traffic agencies (e.g., local, county, and state) within a city's boundaries. These overlapping jurisdictions produce fractures within the road network resulting in the asynchronous operation of traffic signals. SinWaves' proposed the consolidated management of multiple traffic agencies into a single cloud-based traffic management platform capable of coordinating large areas of traffic signals resulting in significant reductions in traffic light wait time, gridlock, and greenhouse gas emissions. 

Hardware solutions for emergency vehicle preemption and public transit priority use expensive sensors that are installed on specific intersections that are selected to improve response time on common routes. This cost can be rather prohibitive even for a modestly sized city, notwithstanding the fact these sensors have a short range which limits their abilities. With a cloud solution that is capable of speaking to each networked intersection, vehicle navigation data can be used to proactively adjust traffic signal timing well in advance, that will favor public transit while also not producing additional delays to other vehicles. For emergency vehicles, cloud coordination of traffic signals can better clear the road ahead by setting the appropriate timing of green signals, which will reduce their risk of a side impact collision and allow them to arrive sooner.

In SinWaves, Inc. (LYT) Phase II proposal, the company set four main technical objectives. They can be summarized as follows:

1) A generalized on-premise traffic agency integration solution (Maestro) that securely connects agency traffic signals to the company's cloud infrastructure, thus enabling the exchange of information between traffic systems and vehicles.

2) Develop internal software tools for the configuration and setup of the applications being researched and developed.

3) The development of a public transit signal priority application that optimizes traffic signal timing from predicted bus arrivals times at intersections. 

4) The development of an emergency vehicle preemption system that can coordinate all traffic signals along a responder's route.

Thanks to achievements made towards these technical objectives and early commercialization efforts, the company was able to attract additional third-party investment resulting in the qualification and award of a Phase IIB. The three major technical objectives of Phase IIB were: 

1) Complete Maestro enhancements and cloud platform development.

2) Scale machine learning for emergency vehicle preemption (EVP) & transit signal priority (TSP).

3) Develop algorithms, machine learning models, and other software logic that is needed to coordinate traffic signals according to travel demands.

Today, the company has been able to make significant progress on every one of these technical objectives. In 2019, SinWaves launched its first demonstration with the City of San Jose, CA, and the Santa Clara Valley Transportation Authority. On 17 traffic signals, the company proved that by using machine learning, historical, and real-time bus location data, traffic signal timing can be optimized to provide priority to transit vehicles without causing noticeable disruptions and delays to all other traffic. The first version of the system had limited ability to prioritize buses at more than one traffic signal. Today the system can accurately predict bus arrival times to three cascading traffic signals. This means the prediction models can now predict up to 150 seconds of future bus trajectory, an improvement of more than 90 seconds from prior prediction models. There is ongoing work to improve this to five cascading traffic signals. 

From the company's fall 2022 deployment in the City of Portland, OR, the system has reduced intersection delays by 75% on the TriMet FX2 bus route. That equates to 6 minutes of faster travel times for this bus route. When the platform was deployed for emergency vehicles in the City of Ranch Cordova, CA, it resulted in 69% faster response times. The achievements made during Phase II/IIB provide a foundation upon which to build additional traffic management applications.
